dt: {bc}one that is {a_link|eminent}, prominent, or lofty: such as
{bc}a person of high rank or attainments
often used as a title for a cardinal

et: Middle English, "exalted position, protuberance," borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French, borrowed from Latin {it}eminentia{/it} "state of standing out or projecting, protuberance," noun derivative of {it}ēminent-, ēminens{/it} "standing out above a surface, projecting, outstanding in merit or importance" {ma}{mat|eminent|}{/ma}
shortdef: a position of prominence or superiority
one that is eminent, prominent, or lofty: such as
a person of high rank or attainments —often used as a title for a cardinal

et: borrowed from French, literally, "gray eminence," nickname of Père Joseph (François du Tremblay) †1638 French monk and diplomat, confidant of Cardinal Richelieu who was known as {it}Éminence Rouge{/it} "red eminence"; from the colors of their respective habits
shortdef: a confidential agent; especially : one exercising unsuspected or unofficial power
a respected authority; specifically : elder statesman

dt: {bc}a person who exercises power behind the scenes

et: translation of French {it}Éminence grise{/it}, nickname of Père Joseph (François Joseph du Tremblay) †1638 French monk and diplomat who was confidant of Cardinal Richelieu, styled {it}Éminence rouge{/it} (red eminence); from the colors of their respective habits
shortdef: a person who exercises power behind the scenes
